metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: CSS Gradients
CSS gradients let you display smooth transitions between two or more specified colors.
content.html: CSS gradients let you display smooth transitions between two or more specified colors.

content.text: CSS defines three types of gradients:
content.html: CSS defines three types of gradients:

content.text: CSS Linear Gradients

To create a linear gradient you must define at least two color stops. Color stops are the colors you want to render smooth transitions among. You can also set a starting point and a direction (or an angle) along with the gradient effect.
content.html: To create a linear gradient you must define at least two color stops. Color stops are the colors you want to render smooth transitions among. You can also set a starting point and a direction (or an angle) along with the gradient effect.

content.text: Syntax
Direction - Top to Bottom (this is default)
content.html: Direction - Top to Bottom (this is default)

content.text: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts at the top. It starts red, transitioning to yellow:
content.html: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts at the top. It starts red, transitioning to yellow:

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: linear-gradient(red, yellow);
}

content.text: Direction - Left to Right
content.html: Direction - Left to Right

content.text: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts from the left. It starts red, transitioning to yellow:
content.html: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts from the left. It starts red, transitioning to yellow:

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: linear-gradient(to right, red , yellow);
}

content.text: Direction - Diagonal
content.html: Direction - Diagonal

content.text: You can make a gradient diagonally by specifying both the horizontal and vertical starting positions.
content.html: You can make a gradient diagonally by specifying both the horizontal and vertical starting positions.

content.text: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts at top left (and goes to bottom right). It starts red, transitioning to yellow:
content.html: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts at top left (and goes to bottom right). It starts red, transitioning to yellow:

syntaxHighlighting.text: #grad {  background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);}
background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);

content.code: #grad {  background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);}

syntax_highlighting.text: #grad {  background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);}
background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: #grad {  background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);}
background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom right, red, yellow);

content.text: Using Angles

If you want more control over the direction of the gradient, you can define an angle, instead of the predefined directions (to bottom, to top, to right, to left, to bottom right, etc.). A value of 0deg is equivalent to "to top". A value of 90deg is equivalent to "to right". A value of 180deg is equivalent to "to bottom".
content.html: If you want more control over the direction of the gradient, you can define an angle, instead of the predefined directions (to bottom, to top, to right, to left, to bottom right, etc.). A value of 0deg is equivalent to "to top". A value of 90deg is equivalent to "to right". A value of 180deg is equivalent to "to bottom".

content.text: Syntax
The following example shows how to use angles on linear gradients:
content.html: The following example shows how to use angles on linear gradients:

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: linear-gradient(180deg, red, yellow);
}

content.text: Using Multiple Color Stops
The following example shows a linear gradient (from top to bottom) with multiple color stops:
content.html: The following example shows a linear gradient (from top to bottom) with multiple color stops:

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: linear-gradient(red, yellow, green);
}

content.text: The following example shows how to create a linear gradient (from left to right) with the color of the rainbow and some text:
content.html: The following example shows how to create a linear gradient (from left to right) with the color of the rainbow and some text:

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: linear-gradient(to right, red,orange,yellow,green,blue,indigo,violet);
}

content.text: Using Transparency
CSS gradients also support transparency, which can be used to create fading effects.
content.html: CSS gradients also support transparency, which can be used to create fading effects.

content.text: To add transparency, we use the rgba() function to define the color stops. The last parameter in the rgba() function can be a value from 0 to 1, and it defines the transparency of the color: 0 indicates full transparency, 1 indicates full color (no transparency).
content.html: To add transparency, we use the rgba() function to define the color stops. The last parameter in the rgba() function can be a value from 0 to 1, and it defines the transparency of the color: 0 indicates full transparency, 1 indicates full color (no transparency).

content.text: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts from the left. It starts fully transparent, transitioning to full color red:
content.html: The following example shows a linear gradient that starts from the left. It starts fully transparent, transitioning to full color red:

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: linear-gradient(to right, rgba(255,0,0,0), rgba(255,0,0,1));
}

content.text: Repeating a linear-gradient
The repeating-linear-gradient() function is used to repeat linear gradients:
content.html: The repeating-linear-gradient() function is used to repeat linear gradients:

content.code_html:
#grad {
  background-image: repeating-linear-gradient(red, yellow 10%, green 20%);
}

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the default direction of a linear gradient in CSS?
content.html: What is the default direction of a linear gradient in CSS?

metadata.question: What is the default direction of a linear gradient in CSS?
